name: Faye I.
comment info:
According to the article, the terms “Latinx”, “AAPI”, “BIPOC”, and “Nonwhite” are the 4 least popular terms in the article.
The term Latinx is often criticized as it does not read like a Spanish word whatsoever. ‘Latinx’ as a term was never intended to be used in Spanish, however I still agree with many Latinos that a word derived from Latin-America should be feasibly pronounced in Spanish. Though ‘Latino’ is a masculine adjective, masculine terms in Spanish are often used as a neutral term as well. If a more neutral term is still desired, you can use Latin-American. I’ve also heard ‘e’ be suggested as a gender-neutral suffix in Spanish, which at least makes sense to say out loud. I described myself as Latine for a time while figuring out my gender, and I enjoyed useing the term-- however I can’t really speak for others as I have lived a much whiter life than a Latino one.
The low usage of AAPI is likely caused by a mix of it not being as widely known to most people as other terms, and the fact that it conflates two different ethnic groups.
The term BIPOC has been used to replace the term POC by some, but it is a new term and from what I can tell it has very little difference from POC. Very few people feel the need to change to the new term due to what is often read as redundancy.
I have no comments on the term nonwhite.

Note that I am not a person of color! If I've said anything ignorant or hurtful, please let me know. No explanation needed, unless you want to give one.

name: Ava Block 4
comment info:
This chart has terms such as “Latinx” and “BIPOC” which I've heard rarely and don’t necessarily know what they stand for. And after researching them they seem to be very inclusive but fairly new. Not many people in my area refer to others using “Latinx”, “BIPOC”, or “A.A.I.P” and usually stick to the more vague terms such as  “Asian” or “Hispanic”. I can see why they aren’t very popular in this study of about 4,500 people with “no” percentages of 78% for Latinx and 70% for BIPOC, likely because as I stated above, they are generally newer terms coming out in the 2000s. It makes sense that newer terms, especially related to race and ethnicity, are not used in order to avoid offending others because the meaning has not yet been globalized. While everyone can do a quick google search, just as I did, many people don’t care to look or even know to look, thus resulting in a large population that doesn’t understand the terms used above. This is why some of the most popular terms are “Hispanic” or “Asian” when asked if Americans use certain terms when referring to race and ethnicity. Even though they are pretty vague, most people don’t know any better. It’s obvious that the longer a word is around for, the more widely accepted it's going to be in contrast to newer terms. 

Part 1

This graph is showing the result of what 4,423 Americans refer to people of different races or ethnicities as. I first noticed Americans are very comfortable using the terms “Hispanic and Asian”. Yet Americans rarely use the terms “BIPOC or A.A.P.I”. I wonder why people are more comfortable saying Hispanic or Asian, maybe because they wanted to be “with the crowd”. I think they should have done a counter survey to see which terms people of different ethnicities would prefer to be called. With that kind of information we could see the differences and make comments about how they differ and which terms are more comfortable for a person of different ethnicity. These days you can offend just about anyone when it comes to talking about race.    Seeing that more people use the word Hispanic than Latinx is because of the fear of being perceived as insensitive. Not everyone has grown up in a household where they talk about diversity, its beauty and what is/isn’t offensive.

name: LH, Block 4
comment info:
In this graph, I see that our society has become hyper focused on labeling each other and fitting into specific groups. Although this graph is about race, an age-old concept, many of the terms didn’t exist until now and are just starting to be used more often. As the world has become more culturally and racially inclusive, we have also realized that maybe some of these phrases are too wide-ranging. Although the newer terms, such as “Latinx” and “BIPOC” haven’t gained a ton of popularity yet, they are starting to catch on. I think this is a good thing for the world because it emphasizes smaller groups within larger ethnic groups. Some of these people may have previously been underrepresented and giving them a specific name can help give them the recognition that they deserve. I also think that sometimes people will use the broader terms, like “Asian” or “Hispanic” at times when it may be more appropriate to use a more particular term. I have noticed at school or around town, people who use these broader terms tend to generalize a group of people, sometimes even stereotype them. 
Part 1

name: Robin
comment info: The first thing I notice when I look at this graph is how many people don’t like the term “Latinx”. I’d never heard of it before and it made me wonder why people seem to dislike it so much. I understand the context behind why it was made, to be a gender neutral alternative to Latino/Latina, and I guess since nonbinary people are a minority it would make sense why most people prefer not to use it. It reminded me of the term “Womxn” which was made as a gender neutral alternative to the word “Woman” but isn’t nearly as inclusive as people act like it is. Although it claims to be more inclusive of trans women, the label just treats them like they’re not real women by making a specific term to separate them from other women. This reminded me of how, in my community (LGBTQ+), there’s often a lot of controversy about what labels or pride flags are outdated and appropriate to use. For example, the progress pride flag was made to highlight trans and POC queer people, but some people don’t like that they’re highlighted in that design because it makes it seem like they weren’t included in the original rainbow flag. The trend I notice on this graph is that most people prefer more general terms like “Asian” rather than “A.A.P.I.” probably because the newer terms that are made to be more inclusive tend to make the people they’re trying to include only feel more isolated. I would probably title this graph “Preferred Racial Terminology of 2023”.

name: X
comment info:
Upon observing the graph, I noticed that the sample size of Americans surveyed was relatively small, consisting of only 4,423 individuals out of the almost 332 million residing in the USA. 
It was also interesting to note that many Americans used terms such as Hispanic, African American, and Asian when referring to people of color.
 This is not surprising, given the prevalence of social media and its impact on shaping individuals' perspectives on ethnicity. 
For example, the term Latinx has been controversial among the Hispanic/Latino community, with some finding it offensive. The graph's significance lies in its reflection of the language and attitudes of Americans as a collective group. Depending on one's race, ethnicity, or gender, they may be more or less likely to use certain words. 
Moreover, the graph is relevant to individuals interested in promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion, as it sheds light on language habits and preferences of different demographic groups. 
Some questions that the graph may provoke include the factors that influence people's language choices, why certain terms are more common than others, and how language use reflects cultural and social changes over time. By analyzing the data, one can gain insights into language patterns among different communities and raise questions about the inclusiveness of language use in their own community.

name: Lilia,  Block 4
comment info:
Hispanic, Asian, African American, and Person of Color. What these terms all have in common is that they are broad, umbrella terms used to describe people of varying ethnicities. What I inferred from this graph is that people use terms that make them feel the most comfortable to avoid offending others. However, I don’t think we should focus on what makes us comfortable, and instead use the term that the people who are of these ethnicities identify with. 
When the Black Lives Matter movement first gained momentum, I remember hearing the broad terms in the news, but I also remember seeing interviews and articles talking about “which term is the best” and “which terms are offensive”. People debating if POC was offensive or not, or which terms included which ethnicities. Beyond that, we put so much energy into arguing over these characterizations when we should be focusing on equality and respecting others regardless of their ethnicity instead.

name: Jonah Harker Block 4
comment info:
This graph is interesting to me because it depicts how humans are so afraid to be wrong; to be judged by others. While some would say LatinX, the majority wouldn’t, either because they don’t know what it means, or because they are scared they could possibly offend someone by using the term wrong, or even worse; using the wrong term.
	People should start becoming more knowledgeable about the terms associated with the different races of the world, because the simple terms like “black”, “asian” and “hispanic”, are extremely vague in regard to what someone ethnicity truly is. As a whole, humans are so scared of being wrong, or even worse, being canceled that they would not ask a question, get to know someone. 
	If you are to speak about others' race or ethnicity to others, or if someone is speaking to you about theirs, having knowledge of the terms they may use to describe themselves is important to getting to know who someone truly is. Because there is a big difference between “non white” and “BIPOC”. The world just needs to be inclusive of everyone, and that means using the right ethnic names.

comment info: There is always a reason behind every graph or statistic, and I think the reason for why the words like “nonwhite”, “BIPOC”, “A.A.P.I”, and “Latinx” are statistically less used is that they are less traditional terms for groups of people, and the main people who use them more than likely inhabit the hyper politically correct sector of humans. For example, according to the Journal of Hispanic Higher Education, the first instance of the term Latinx in academic literature was in 2013. This means that the word has not really had much time to catch on to the general populace. Another example would be the term A.A.P.I, which I had never heard of. comment info:
There were many, many great headlines for this graph.  Our appreciation for all that were submitted. Here are only a few:

“As Language Evolves, Americans Weigh In on Words to Describe Race and Ethnicity” by Lainie of Kentucky; “Woke or Broke?: Will Politically Correct Lingo Catch On?” by Clara of Georgetown Visitation Preparatory School; "Words Americans Use When Talking about Identity" by Metropolitan Montessori Middle School in New York City; “Call Me by My Name” by Ashley of Florida; two from Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey – “A New Generation of Terms: Which Do You Identify With?” by Ashley and “Censorship or Respect: Is Terminology Affecting the Way We See Each Other?” by Samuel, and two from Eaglecrest High School in Aurora, Colorado – “What Will America Call Me Today?” by Temsalet and “America Speaks: Words Americans Would and Wouldn't Say” by Ciaran.

There is no graph for next week.  The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, March 17 with moderation on Wednesday, March 29.  The topic – the Anthropocene.  
 
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who uses words like most Baby Boomers (habits die hard), and Sara Stoudt, assistant professor of math at Bucknell in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, who as a statistician knows that word choice really does matter.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs are about what proportion of Americans use specific words to describe some ethnicities and races.  The results come from an online survey of 4,423 adults in December 2022. The survey was weighted on gender, age, race, education and region, with a margin of error of plus or minus 1 percentage point. Word choice is extremely contextual, so they asked people simply if they used a term, not whether they preferred one term over another.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online for the four questions.  By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the free link to the online article that included these graphs.  
You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, March 17 with moderation on Wednesday, March 29.  The topic – the Anthropocene!

Latinx, A.A.P.I., and BIPOC are the labels most rarely used by Americans. Hispanic, Asian, African American and Person of Color are the most often used words. name: Keona T.
comment info:
Americans: Race Words, Are they "Okay" to Say
I notice that 87% of Americans would say the word "Hispanic" whereas only 22% would say "Latinx". It appears that within races, there is always a word people prefer to say over others. This can also be seen in the Asian race with "Asian" at 81% and "A.A.P.I" at 27%. I wonder why people aren't more inclusive on phrases and words as they begin to become more prevalent in our lives. The words "Person of color" and "BIPOC" are brought up more and more throughout our daily lives, yet less than 50% would use those words. I don't understand why because they aren't harmful words, etc. This relates to my community because in my high school we have hundreds of different races, but I never noticed there were only select words used. For example, I hear "Hispanic" or "Mexican" a lot more than other words like "Latino" or specifying the type of latino. On the other hand, there are hundred of different kids of African descent at our school, and all I hear is "Black". It seems like there are just very few recognition of other words or races and only generalized terms. This graph shows the percent of Americans who say or don't say specific "race words".

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Keona T. I agree that there is definitely a term that more people prefer. I wonder if there are terms that have not emerged yet.

name: Joelyna
comment info:
1. Americans are least likely to use the terms Latinx, A.A.P.I., and BIPOC. The most common words are Hispanic, Asian, African American, and Person of Color. Latinx, which is intended to include all Latinos, is the least frequently used and newest word in the list. The least popular words on the graph are more recent expressions that have gained attention due to racial unrest and the growth of social media. This could explain why other terms are more commonly used than these ones, particularly the way America defines races and ethnicities.

2. Why aren't the most inclusive words used more frequently? Is this because the terms are still so new and the majority of people still don't understand them? A.A.P.I. is also much less common than the more straightforward term Asian, whereas both black terms for black people are much closer to what Americans would say when compared to any other race. Maybe because there are as many black Americans as there are white Americans.

3. In relation to my community, I can also understand why some of the terms selected are used more frequently than others. Being Latina, I could also comprehend why the term "Latinx" isn't used more often. This is because it is the most recent and, in my opinion, is not as necessary as people think since the term "Latino," despite being a masculine word, can be used broadly to describe anyone of Latin ancestry.

4. "POC or BIPOC? Preferred Racial Terms by Americans"

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Daniela Good question about the design of the graphic. One strategy for planning a data visualization is to think about what comparisons will be most interesting to a reader and then to make that comparison as easy to see as possible. Grouping like terms here make it easier to compare within terms that someone might use in a similar context. For example, we can easily see that "Hispanic" is used by a higher proportion of respondents than "Latinx".

name: Mrs. Rategan
comment info:
1) What do we notice?

A lot of students noticed that at least one term on the graph was unfamiliar to them, such as "Latinx" and "Nonwhite". According to this chart, black is not an offensive term; this brought up, among students, how to respectfully address someone. Many students felt that some of the words on the chart are difficult to use and still sound respectful. We also noticed that there was nothing on the chart to imply "it depends." Students pointed out that answers could vary depending on the person. Using these words feels very personal to the individual. A lot of people use broader terms like "Asian" and "Hispanic". There are no options for people with mixed races, which we would have liked to see. 

2) What do you wonder? 

Some of my students were confused about some terms, such as AAPI and BIPOC.

3) How does this relate to you and your community.

It helps us to see/discuss what is appropriate when referring to other people.

4) Catchy headlines?

Correct Terminology or Offensive Words?

name: Liza Bondurant
comment info:
I notice a inverse relationship between the percentage of Americans who would say the terms and the percentage of people from the group the term is intended to describe who prefer to be called by that term. 

For example 87% of Americans would say "Hispanic" and only 22% would say "Latinx." It is my understanding that this group of people prefer the more inclusive term "Latinx."

I wonder if age or region of the country are associated with the words the people would and wouldn't say. 

My husband is Filipino. He has been picked on throughout his life. Kids on the school bus would call him "squint eyes." He also felt pressure to perform well in school because he was represented the "model minority." I think there has been an uptick in hate crimes against A.A.P.I. people since COVID. 

I think folx prefer the term "BIPOC." The term includes more people. Therefore, more people feel represented. More people = more power. 

The title I would use is "Label jars, not people."

replies.comment info:
HI, @Liza Bondurant --

You write that "I think folx prefer the term "BIPOC.""  But, only 30% of respondents say that they would use it.  Why do you think such a low percentage use this word?

name: Ava
comment info:
What I notice:
- the highest percentage of people say “Hispanic” and “Asian” which makes sense because most hospitals use it to learn more about your health background and it’s a general word that I don’t think many people take offense to
- The lowest percentage of people say “Latnix” and “AAPI” which makes sense because it zeroes in on a certain race and many people would probably take offense to a stranger specifying their race
- most of the general race descriptions have a majority of “yes” and the race specific descriptions have a majority of “no”
- person of color is the only one that has a pretty much balanced number of people, which means some say it and some don’t

What I wonder:
* Does “latino” and “latinx” mean the same thing? 
* Why are most people okay with saying “latino” and “hispanic” but not “latinx”? (same thing with asian, asian americans, and “AAPI”)
* why do most people think they would take offense to “BIPOC” and “AAPI” but not “Black” or “Hispanic”?

A headline could be: Offending Race Cloud; What’s Right and What’s Wrong?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ava --

You ask many great questions.  

Think hard what is the root meaning of “Hispanic.”  Does this correspondent to who may be included in this group?  

How about the root meaning of Asian vs. Asian American.  

When were the words Latinx, BOPOC and AAPI introduced?  May this have anything to do with whether people would use these words?

What I notice: The "newer" terms are those that tend to be used less. Words that have been used for years prior (such as "African American" or "Asian American") tend to be used far more often than terms that have cropped up in a more recent evolution of language (such as "Latinx" or "BIPOC").

What I wonder: What did the racial and ethnic demography of survey-takers look like? 

How this relates to me & my community: My generation, Gen Z, is the most diverse generation in the history of America thus far, and as a society, our language is evolving to reflect that. This graph represents the growing pains of inclusive language in an ever-broadening world.

What’s going on?: As Language Evolves, Americans Weigh In On  Words to Describe Race and Ethnicity
